page.title: 17BROADWELL MANOR
page.content: There has been a manor house on this site since the 10th century. The present house, with 25 rooms, was substantially rebuilt in 1757 in the Classical Early Georgian style following a fire which destroyed most of the Jacobean house of which only the west wing survives. It was sited by the spring from which the village derives its name. There is still a well in the cellars. The extensive outbuildings include the original Tudor brew-house and a recently restored stable yard. There are many fine old trees in the grounds with formal lawns, a newly created herb garden, an old walled vegetable garden and paddocks. The present owners have lived there for 15 years and love its elegant Georgian proportions but find it hard to run and especially to heat in the winter!
